elements.content: Two new calcium coordination polymers, [Ca3(btc)2(H2O)12] (1) and [Ca2(btc)(pzc)(H2O)3] (2) (btc = benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate, pzc = pyrazine-2-carboxylate), have been synthesized using the hydro/solvothermal method and have been characterized using X-ray diffraction, IR, UV–vis, thermogravimetric analysis, and fluorescence analysis. The structure of compound 1 is a three-dimensional framework consisting of helical chains of calcium coordination polymers, while that of compound 2 is a double layered network in which the inorganic zigzag chains of calcium coordination polyhedra are linked by organic ligands. Both compounds show blue fluorescence when excited with UV light. Density functional theory calculations on electronic absorption spectra of organic ligands and calcium coordination polymers are discussed.

elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) materials, which are also known as coordination polymers, have attracted extensive research studies because of their potential applications in many areas, such as gas storage, separations, sensors, and heterogeneous catalysis. The general approach of making these materials is usually the fabrication of metal ion building units and multidentate organic ligands in appropriate solvents under hydro(sovol)thermal conditions. From the point view of coordination chemistry, the assembly of the building units into designed MOF structures is controlled by many parameters, such as the metal coordination geometry, the Lewis acidity of the metal, the Lewis basicity of the ligands, and the number and type of donor atoms and their orientations. In recent years, noncovalent interactions, such as hydrogen-bonding, ionic interactions, and π–π stacking between building units are also considered as important factors in the self-organization of the frameworks. Although it is impossible to exactly control all of these factors at the same time when designing a MOF, it is usually realistic to tune the combination of suitable metal ions and proper organic linkers in order to tailor structural geometries, connectivity, and subsequent properties, such as the adsorption of small molecules. In recent years, in addition to transition metals, main group metals have also been used to synthesize novel metal–organic network topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic framework (MOF) materials, which are also known as coordination polymers, have attracted extensive research studies because of their potential applications in many areas, such as gas storage, separations, sensors, and heterogeneous catalysis. The general approach of making these materials is usually the fabrication of metal ion building units and multidentate organic ligands in appropriate solvents under hydro(sovol)thermal conditions. From the point view of coordination chemistry, the assembly of the building units into designed MOF structures is controlled by many parameters, such as the metal coordination geometry, the Lewis acidity of the metal, the Lewis basicity of the ligands, and the number and type of donor atoms and their orientations. In recent years, noncovalent interactions, such as hydrogen-bonding, ionic interactions, and π-π stacking between building units are also considered as important factors in the self-organization of the frameworks. Although it is impossible to exactly control all of these factors at the same time when designing a MOF, it is usually realistic to tune the combination of suitable metal ions and proper organic linkers in order to tailor structural geometries, connectivity, and subsequent properties, such as the adsorption of small molecules. In recent years, in addition to transition metals, main group metals have also been used to synthesize novel metal-organic network topologies.

elements.content: In contrast to the huge amount of MOFs built from transition metal ions reported in the literature, there are a relatively limited number of examples based on the alkaline earth metals; however, a few studies on magnesium and calcium have been reported. Recent reports show that doping alkaline earth metals or alkaline metals in MOFs may enhance their ability for gas storage due to the stronger binding capability of these metals to certain gases such as CO2 or H2. Moreover, the assembly of MOFs from calcium and polycarboxylate linkers, including aliphatic or aromatic carboxylates ligands, has been investigated and is receiving increasing interest. Because of their flexibility as mono-, bi-, or multidentate ligands, carboxylic acids, such as btc and pzc, have been investigated for the synthesis of coordination polymers with a diverse range of topologies and conformations. We are interested in the synthesis of porous materials and the study of their properties, such as their ability to absorb/remove mercury in flue gas of power plants. Our approach is to develop novel materials based on alkaline earth MOFs to specifically recognize, bind, and capture mercury. Herein we report the synthesis and structural characterization of two new crystalline alkaline earth metal coordination polymer phases, [Ca3(btc)2(H2O)12] (1) and [Ca2(btc)(pzc)(H2O)3] (2). The thermal properties and luminescent behavior of these materials are also discussed.

elements.content: The infrared spectra were recorded from 400 to 4000 cm–1 on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. The thermogravimetric data were collected on a TA Q5000 TGA instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 from room temperature to 800 °C in an air atmosphere. Powder X-ray analysis was performed on an ARL Thermo X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The resulting crystal structure was used to simulate the powder pattern, which was found to have good agreement with the experimental data. Fluorescence spectra were obtained by a PerkinElmer LS55 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were obtained using a Varian Cary 100 UV–vis spectrophotometer equipped with the DRA-CA-30 diffuse reflectance accessory.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The infrared spectra were recorded from 400 to 4000 cm-1 on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. The thermogravimetric data were collected on a TA Q5000 TGA instrument at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 from room temperature to 800 °C in an air atmosphere. Powder X-ray analysis was performed on an ARL Thermo X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The resulting crystal structure was used to simulate the powder pattern, which was found to have good agreement with the experimental data. Fluorescence spectra were obtained by a PerkinElmer LS55 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were obtained using a Varian Cary 100 UV-vis spectrophotometer equipped with the DRA-CA-30 diffuse reflectance accessory.

elements.content: Compound 1 was synthesized from a mixture of calcium chloride, benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, ethylenediamine (en), and water. A typical synthesis is as follows: 1.0 mL of water containing 0.098 g of H3btc were mixed with a 1.0 mL aqueous solution of 0.217 g of CaCl2 and stirred. To the resulting mixture, 0.036 g of en aqueous solution (en/H2O ratio, 1:2) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min using a magnetic stir bar. The pH of this mixture was adjusted with 2 M NaOH to approximately 9.4. The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon bag, sealed and placed in a 45 mL reaction vessel, and heated in an oven at 180 °C for 24 h. Colorless crystals were filtered and dried in air for overnight (yield: 0.117 g). The purity of the products was determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements (Figure S1, ). IR (cm–1): 3461s, 3304s, 3204s, 3126s, 1651m (sh), 1611s, 1555s, 1434m, 1378s, 1208w, 1109w, 935(w), 805w, 761m, 720m, 628w (Figure S2, ). UV DRS (solid) 260 nm, 290 nm, 310 nm (shoulder).

Compound [Ca3(btc)2(H2O)12] (1)

Compound 1 was synthesized from a mixture of calcium chloride, benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, ethylenediamine (en), and water. A typical synthesis is as follows: 1.0 mL of water containing 0.098 g of H3btc were mixed with a 1.0 mL aqueous solution of 0.217 g of CaCl2 and stirred. To the resulting mixture, 0.036 g of en aqueous solution (en/H2O ratio, 1:2) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min using a magnetic stir bar. The pH of this mixture was adjusted with 2 M NaOH to approximately 9.4. The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon bag, sealed and placed in a 45 mL reaction vessel, and heated in an oven at 180 °C for 24 h. Colorless crystals were filtered and dried in air for overnight (yield: 0.117 g). The purity of the products was determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements (Figure S1, ). IR (cm-1): 3461s, 3304s, 3204s, 3126s, 1651m (sh), 1611s, 1555s, 1434m, 1378s, 1208w, 1109w, 935(w), 805w, 761m, 720m, 628w (Figure S2, ). UV DRS (solid) 260 nm, 290 nm, 310 nm (shoulder).

elements.content: Compound 2 was synthesized from a mixture of calcium nitrate hexahydrate, benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid, dimethylformide (DMF), and water. A typical synthesis is as follows: a mixture of 0.125 g of btc and 0.072 g of pzc in 1.0 mL of DMF was added to a 1.0 mL aqueous solution containing 0.291 g of Ca(NO3)·6H2O. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min and the pH was then adjusted with 2 M NaOH to approximately 6.98. The reaction mixtures were transferred to a Teflon bag, sealed and placed in a 45 mL reaction vessel, and heated in an oven at 130 °C for 24 h. Colorless crystals were filtered and dried in air overnight (yield: 0.113 g). The purity of the products was determined by PXRD measurements (Figure S3, ). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3342s (br), 1620s, 1551s, 1431s, 1376s, 1162w, 1112w, 1058w, 1037w, 732m, 663m (Figure S4, ). UV DRS (solid) 250 nm, 275 nm, 310 nm (shoulder).

Compound [Ca2(btc)(pzc)(H2O)3] (2)

Compound 2 was synthesized from a mixture of calcium nitrate hexahydrate, benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid, dimethylformide (DMF), and water. A typical synthesis is as follows: a mixture of 0.125 g of btc and 0.072 g of pzc in 1.0 mL of DMF was added to a 1.0 mL aqueous solution containing 0.291 g of Ca(NO3)⋅6H2O. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min and the pH was then adjusted with 2 M NaOH to approximately 6.98. The reaction mixtures were transferred to a Teflon bag, sealed and placed in a 45 mL reaction vessel, and heated in an oven at 130 °C for 24 h. Colorless crystals were filtered and dried in air overnight (yield: 0.113 g). The purity of the products was determined by PXRD measurements (Figure S3, ). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3342s (br), 1620s, 1551s, 1431s, 1376s, 1162w, 1112w, 1058w, 1037w, 732m, 663m (Figure S4, ). UV DRS (solid) 250 nm, 275 nm, 310 nm (shoulder).

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Quazar diffractometer with an Apex II CCD area detector. The data were processed with the SAINT software and corrected for absorption with SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods SHELXTL V.6.10 package and was refined against F2 by weighted full-matrix least-squares calculations. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined allowing for anisotropic displacement. Hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier maps. Atomic scattering factors were taken from the International Tables for Crystallography. Crystal data and relevant details of the structure determinations are summarized in Table , and selected geometrical parameters are given in Table s1 ().
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker Quazar diffractometer with an Apex II CCD area detector. The data were processed with the SAINT software and corrected for absorption with SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods SHELXTL V.6.10 package and was refined against F2 by weighted full-matrix least-squares calculations. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined allowing for anisotropic displacement. Hydrogen atoms were located from the difference Fourier maps. Atomic scattering factors were taken from the International Tables for Crystallography. Crystal data and relevant details of the structure determinations are summarized in Table , and selected geometrical parameters are given in Table s1 ().

A series of density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed for the btc and pzc ligands (and the free acids) using the Gaussian 09 electronic structure package. In these calculations, we have utilized optimized molecular structures for the gas phase ligands as well as for an implicit solvent reaction field (water) based on the polarizable continuum model. We have also extracted the btc and pzc ion structures from the single crystal XRD determined unit-cells of compounds 1 and 2 and have employed fixed electrostatic charges to mimic the presence of calcium ions (2+ charges). The Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange and gradient corrected correlation functionals were used for all calculations with Dunning’s double-ζ correlation consistent basis set (cc-pVDZ). Electronic transition energies and oscillator strengths were calculated using the time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) method, and a natural transition orbital (NTO) analysis was used to identify the nature of the electronic transitions in the experimental UV spectra.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Structure Calculations

A series of density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed for the btc and pzc ligands (and the free acids) using the Gaussian 09 electronic structure package. In these calculations, we have utilized optimized molecular structures for the gas phase ligands as well as for an implicit solvent reaction field (water) based on the polarizable continuum model. We have also extracted the btc and pzc ion structures from the single crystal XRD determined unit-cells of compounds 1 and 2 and have employed fixed electrostatic charges to mimic the presence of calcium ions (2+ charges). The Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange and gradient corrected correlation functionals were used for all calculations with Dunning's double-ζ correlation consistent basis set (cc-pVDZ). Electronic transition energies and oscillator strengths were calculated using the time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) method, and a natural transition orbital (NTO) analysis was used to identify the nature of the electronic transitions in the experimental UV spectra.

elements.content: The structure of compound 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) framework consisting of Ca ions, btc ligands, and coordinated waters. As shown in Figure a, its asymmetric unit consists of one and a half Ca atoms, two halves of btc ligands, and six coordinated water molecules. Ca(1) binds to four water molecules and two carboxylate oxygens of two btc ligands (Figure b). Ca(2) is eight-coordinated by four water molecules and four carboxylate oxygen atoms of two btc ligands (Figure c). The two btc ligands share the same coordination environment: coordinating to three Ca atoms with its three carboxylate groups (Figure d). The Ca–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.299(1)–2.967(2) Å. Bond valence calculations gave a value of +2.07 for both Ca(1) and Ca(2) cations.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description of Compound 1 

The structure of compound 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) framework consisting of Ca ions, btc ligands, and coordinated waters. As shown in Figure a, its asymmetric unit consists of one and a half Ca atoms, two halves of btc ligands, and six coordinated water molecules. Ca(1) binds to four water molecules and two carboxylate oxygens of two btc ligands (Figure b). Ca(2) is eight-coordinated by four water molecules and four carboxylate oxygen atoms of two btc ligands (Figure c). The two btc ligands share the same coordination environment: coordinating to three Ca atoms with its three carboxylate groups (Figure d). The Ca-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.299(1)-2.967(2) Å. Bond valence calculations gave a value of +2.07 for both Ca(1) and Ca(2) cations.

elements.content: (a) The asymmetric unit; (b) the coordination environment of Ca(1); (c) the coordination environment of Ca(2); and (d) the coordination environment of btc in compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The asymmetric unit; (b) the coordination environment of Ca(1); (c) the coordination environment of Ca(2); and (d) the coordination environment of btc in compound 1.

elements.content: Ca(1) atoms forms a helical chain (Figure a) along the a direction, with adjacent Ca atoms linked through two carboxylate oxygens of a btc ligand. In the chain, the Ca(1) atoms line up in two parallel columns along the a axis with the nearest Ca(1)···Ca(1) distance of 6.726 Å. Hydrogen bonds form along the column between water molecules from neighboring Ca(1) atoms (O(3W)–H···O(1W): 2.943 Å). The neighboring Ca(1) atoms from different columns are linked by btc ligands to form the helical chain. The dihedral angle between neighboring benzene rings is calculated as 11.83(6)°, and C···C distances are in the range 3.08–3.57 Å, indicating π–π interactions between aromatic rings. The structure of 1 contains both left- and right-handed helical chains; hence, the crystal is achiral. The third carboxylate of each linking btc ligand points toward the opposite direction of its neighboring btc ligands in the helical chain and coordinates to Ca(2) cations, which link the helical chains of the same handedness into a chiral layer parallel to the ab plane (Figure b). Neighboring chains in the layer are related by shifting a half unit along the a axis, and neighboring layers contain chains of different handedness.

In the chain, the Ca(1) atoms line up in two parallel columns along the a axis with the nearest Ca(1)⋅⋅⋅Ca(1) distance of 6.726 Å. Hydrogen bonds form along the column between water molecules from neighboring Ca(1) atoms (O(3W)-H⋅⋅⋅O(1W): 2.943 Å). The neighboring Ca(1) atoms from different columns are linked by btc ligands to form the helical chain. The dihedral angle between neighboring benzene rings is calculated as 11.83(6)°, and C⋅⋅⋅C distances are in the range 3.08-3.57 Å, indicating π-π interactions between aromatic rings. The structure of 1 contains both left- and right-handed helical chains; hence, the crystal is achiral. The third carboxylate of each linking btc ligand points toward the opposite direction of its neighboring btc ligands in the helical chain and coordinates to Ca(2) cations, which link the helical chains of the same handedness into a chiral layer parallel to the ab plane (Figure b). Neighboring chains in the layer are related by shifting a half unit along the a axis, and neighboring layers contain chains of different handedness.

elements.content: Each Ca(1) cation in a layer is sharing two water molecules with Ca(2) from the adjacent layers (Ca(1)–O, 2.967(2); Ca(2)–O, 2.539(2) Å), forming a 3D framework (Figure c), in which the layers are stacked along the c direction in an ABAB... manner. Thus, Ca(1) connects to four unshared waters while Ca(2) binds to two unshared waters. These waters point to voids formed by the framework of 1 and can be potentially removed to form open metal sites on Ca ions. Compound 1 can be viewed as a 3,6-connected net or an ant (anatase) net, according to the topological analysis using TOPOS40 program. The 6-connected node is a calcium cluster {Ca3(H2O)2}.

Thus, Ca(1) connects to four unshared waters while Ca(2) binds to two unshared waters. These waters point to voids formed by the framework of 1 and can be potentially removed to form open metal sites on Ca ions. Compound 1 can be viewed as a 3,6-connected net or an ant (anatase) net, according to the topological analysis using TOPOS40 program. The 6-connected node is a calcium cluster {Ca3(H2O)2}.

elements.content: To date, only three calcium/btc based coordination polymers [Ca3(btc)2(H2O)12] (1b), [Ca(Hbtc)(H2O)2] (3), and [Ca3(btc)2(DMF)2(H2O)2]3·3H2O (4) have been reported. Compounds 1b and 3 are layered structures, while 4 is a 3D framework. Compound 1 represents the second 3D framework constructed from btc and calcium building units.

elements.content: The structure of compound 2 is a double layered network. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 2 consists of two unique calcium ions, one btc, one pzc, and three coordinated water molecules. Ca(1) is eight-coordinated to six carboxylate oxygens of three btc and one pzc ligands, and two water molecules (Figure b), while Ca(2) is seven-coordinated to five carboxylate oxygens of btc/pzc ligand, one nitrogen of pzc, and one oxygen of water (Figure c). The btc ligand is connected to six calcium ions using its three carboxylate groups. The pzc ligand binds to two Ca ions via its two O atoms and one N atom, leaving one N atom uncoordinated (Figure d). The Ca–O distances are 2.297(1)–2.771(1) Å and Ca–N is 2.596(2) Å. Bond valence calculations gave a value of +2.05 for Ca(1) and 2.23 for Ca(2).
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Compound 2 

The structure of compound 2 is a double layered network. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 2 consists of two unique calcium ions, one btc, one pzc, and three coordinated water molecules. Ca(1) is eight-coordinated to six carboxylate oxygens of three btc and one pzc ligands, and two water molecules (Figure b), while Ca(2) is seven-coordinated to five carboxylate oxygens of btc/pzc ligand, one nitrogen of pzc, and one oxygen of water (Figure c). The btc ligand is connected to six calcium ions using its three carboxylate groups. The pzc ligand binds to two Ca ions via its two O atoms and one N atom, leaving one N atom uncoordinated (Figure d). The Ca-O distances are 2.297(1)-2.771(1) Å and Ca-N is 2.596(2) Å. Bond valence calculations gave a value of +2.05 for Ca(1) and 2.23 for Ca(2).

elements.content: (a) The asymmetric unit; (b) the coordination environment of Ca(1); (c) the coordination environment of Ca(2); and (d) the coordination environment of btc and pzc in compound 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The asymmetric unit; (b) the coordination environment of Ca(1); (c) the coordination environment of Ca(2); and (d) the coordination environment of btc and pzc in compound 2.

elements.content: The Ca(1) ion is sharing two oxygen atoms with Ca(2) ion to form a dimer unit {Ca2O12N}, which in turn is connected to two neighboring dimers into a zigzag chain by corner sharing the oxygen atoms (Figure a). These chains then form a layered structure by sharing btc ligands between neighboring chains. An interesting feature of 2 is that only one of the two pzc nitrogen atoms coordinates to a calcium ion. The other nitrogen atom of pzc from one chain forms strong hydrogen bonds (O(3W)···N(2), 2.809(2) Å) to water molecules on the adjacent chains. This provides additional force in the assembly of inorganic chains to adopt a layered structure (Figure c). Strong hydrogen bonds (O(1W)···O(2), 2.709(2) Å; O(2W)···O(3), 2.774(2) Å) also formed between layers to hold the layers into a 3D network. Topological analysis reveals that compound 2 has a 3,4,6-connected net with a point symbol of {45.6}2{46.66.83}{4}.

elements.content: Although there are many coordination polymers containing the pzc ligand, to the best of our knowledge, no Ca/pzc based MOFs have been reported so far. Ptasiewicz-Bak et al. reported a monomeric calcium complex based on pzc ligand [Ca(pzc)2(H2O)4]. Therefore, compound 2 represents the first pzc based Ca coordination polymer synthesized from hydrothermal reactions.

elements.content: To study the thermal stability, a thermogravimetric analysis was performed on both compounds 1 and 2 (Figure ). Crystalline samples were heated from 30 to 900 °C in air at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. An initial weight loss of approximately 19.0% over a temperature range of 40–140 °C was observed for compound 1. This could be attributed to the loss of eight coordinated water molecules per formula unit (calculated 19.2%). In the range of 140–350 °C, a further loss of 4.9% (calc 4.8%) could be the loss of two water molecules per formula unit. The weight loss of 51.1% (520–700 °C, calc 50.9%) is attributed to the removal and decomposition of the btc ligand and the formation of calcium oxide.

elements.content: In order to investigate the electronic structure of the compounds, the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) of 1 and 2 has been studied. The UV–vis spectra of both ligands in aqueous solution and solid samples have been also recorded for comparison and are presented in (Figures s10–s13). The UV–vis spectra of free Hpzc ligand in aqueous solution exhibits three bands at 205, 268, and 312 nm. The two strong bands at higher energy level are assigned to π–π* transitions and the weak band to n–π* transition. The strong π–π* transition band of free H3btc ligand in aqueous solution is located at 209 nm with a shoulder at 238 nm. The n–π* transition band at ∼294 nm of free H3btc ligand is very weak. The transition band positions of the solid free ligand samples in their UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra are rather different from the solution absorption spectra. The DRS of pzc shows two broad bands at 250 nm (shoulder at 210 nm) and 315 nm. The btc ligand has two bands at 250 nm (shoulder at 210 nm) and 285 nm. The bands at lower energy can be assigned to the n–π* transition, which is stronger in solid state samples.

elements.content:
The fluorescent spectra of compounds 1 and 2 as solid suspensions in water were studied at room temperature and their emission spectra are depicted in Figure .

The only organic ligand in compound 1 is btc, whose free form (H3btc), when excited at 334 nm, shows the emission at λmax = 370 nm, which can be assigned to the π*–n transition (Figure s9, ). The emission spectrum of 1 shows a peak at 406 nm when excited at 308 nm. The hypsochromic shift of the excitation in 1 (from 334 to 308 nm) could possibly be explained by a change of the n orbital energy level on oxygen atoms due to the coordination of Ca2+ and the hydrogen bonding to the carboxylate oxo groups. The π* orbitals, however, might be slightly affected due to the twisting of the btc ligand away from the coplanar form (the dihedral angles between the carboxylate groups and the benzene aromatic ring: ca. 12.53°, 7.83°, 3.3°, 15.9° for C(5), C(6), C(11), C(12), respectively). It is not clear why emission of 1 shows a hypochromic shift. However, it has been suggested in the presence of a cation that strongly interacts with the lone pair of the carbonyl group, the n–π* state is likely to be shifted to higher energy so that the lowest excited state becomes a π–π* transition. Thus, it is possible that the emission in 1 is from a low lying π*−π transition. Similar to other reported Ca coordination polymers, it is reasonable to assume in 1 that the emission is essentially a ligand-centered transition.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Emissions

The fluorescent spectra of compounds 1 and 2 as solid suspensions in water were studied at room temperature and their emission spectra are depicted in Figure .

The only organic ligand in compound 1 is btc, whose free form (H3btc), when excited at 334 nm, shows the emission at λmax = 370 nm, which can be assigned to the π*-n transition (Figure s9, ). The emission spectrum of 1 shows a peak at 406 nm when excited at 308 nm. The hypsochromic shift of the excitation in 1 (from 334 to 308 nm) could possibly be explained by a change of the n orbital energy level on oxygen atoms due to the coordination of Ca2+ and the hydrogen bonding to the carboxylate oxo groups. The π* orbitals, however, might be slightly affected due to the twisting of the btc ligand away from the coplanar form (the dihedral angles between the carboxylate groups and the benzene aromatic ring: ca. 12.53°, 7.83°, 3.3°, 15.9° for C(5), C(6), C(11), C(12), respectively). It is not clear why emission of 1 shows a hypochromic shift. However, it has been suggested in the presence of a cation that strongly interacts with the lone pair of the carbonyl group, the n-π* state is likely to be shifted to higher energy so that the lowest excited state becomes a π-π* transition. Thus, it is possible that the emission in 1 is from a low lying π*-π transition. Similar to other reported Ca coordination polymers, it is reasonable to assume in 1 that the emission is essentially a ligand-centered transition.

elements.content: Compound 2 contains mixed organic ligands of btc and pzc. The free ligand of Hpzc exhibits similar emission (λex = 357 and λem = 427 nm, Figure s10, ) to free btc ligand. Upon excitation at 347 nm, the luminescence spectra of compound 2 exhibit two emissions: 394 and 410 nm, which is originated from btc and pzc respectively. The excitation of 2 slightly blue-shifted when compared with the free pzc ligand, and this is likely due to the coordination of N to Ca ions in 2. The two emission peaks in 2 can be attributed to ligand-centered transitions.

elements.content: To better understand the electronic structure of the coordination polymer, we have performed DFT and TD-DFT calculations on the optimized free acids H3btc and Hpzc, and the ligand ions btc and pzc. These studies are presented in full detail in the . To summarize, the simulated UV spectra for the H3btc and Hpzc acids and the ligands exhibit several π → π* transitions in the range of 200–350 nm. These calculated wavelengths and oscillator strengths are in excellent agreement with the experimentally observed spectra of the free acids in aqueous solution. We have also performed a series of electronic structure calculations on the btc and pzc ligand ions using molecular geometries extracted from the PXRD crystallographic structures of compounds 1 and 2. In order to mimic the effect of the calcium ions we incorporated static electric charges (2+); see Figures d and d. While these calculations did show some modification of the ligand’s electronic transitions, the simulated spectra did not correspond well with the observed UV DRS spectra for compounds 1 and 2, and we believe that an explicit treatment of calcium and water molecules within the ligand’s coordination environment will be required in order to model the electronic properties of these compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Structure Calculations and Optical Spectra

To better understand the electronic structure of the coordination polymer, we have performed DFT and TD-DFT calculations on the optimized free acids H3btc and Hpzc, and the ligand ions btc and pzc. These studies are presented in full detail in the . To summarize, the simulated UV spectra for the H3btc and Hpzc acids and the ligands exhibit several π → π* transitions in the range of 200-350 nm. These calculated wavelengths and oscillator strengths are in excellent agreement with the experimentally observed spectra of the free acids in aqueous solution. We have also performed a series of electronic structure calculations on the btc and pzc ligand ions using molecular geometries extracted from the PXRD crystallographic structures of compounds 1 and 2. In order to mimic the effect of the calcium ions we incorporated static electric charges (2+); see Figures d and d. While these calculations did show some modification of the ligand's electronic transitions, the simulated spectra did not correspond well with the observed UV DRS spectra for compounds 1 and 2, and we believe that an explicit treatment of calcium and water molecules within the ligand's coordination environment will be required in order to model the electronic properties of these compounds.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 was synthesized from a mixture of calcium chloride, benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, ethylenediamine (en), and water. A typical synthesis is as follows: 1.0 mL of water containing 0.098 g of H3btc were mixed with a 1.0 mL aqueous solution of 0.217 g of CaCl2 and stirred. To the resulting mixture, 0.036 g of en aqueous solution (en/H2O ratio, 1:2) was added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min using a magnetic stir bar. The pH of this mixture was adjusted with 2 M NaOH to approximately 9.4. The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon bag, sealed and placed in a 45 mL reaction vessel, and heated in an oven at 180 °C for 24 h. Colorless crystals were filtered and dried in air for overnight (yield: 0.117 g). The purity of the products was determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements (Figure S1, ). IR (cm–1): 3461s, 3304s, 3204s, 3126s, 1651m (sh), 1611s, 1555s, 1434m, 1378s, 1208w, 1109w, 935(w), 805w, 761m, 720m, 628w (Figure S2, ). UV DRS (solid) 260 nm, 290 nm, 310 nm (shoulder).

Compound [Ca<sub>2</sub>(btc)(pzc)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was synthesized from a mixture of calcium nitrate hexahydrate, benzene 1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid, dimethylformide (DMF), and water. A typical synthesis is as follows: a mixture of 0.125 g of btc and 0.072 g of pzc in 1.0 mL of DMF was added to a 1.0 mL aqueous solution containing 0.291 g of Ca(NO3)·6H2O. The resulting mixture was stirred for 30 min and the pH was then adjusted with 2 M NaOH to approximately 6.98. The reaction mixtures were transferred to a Teflon bag, sealed and placed in a 45 mL reaction vessel, and heated in an oven at 130 °C for 24 h. Colorless crystals were filtered and dried in air overnight (yield: 0.113 g). The purity of the products was determined by PXRD measurements (Figure S3, ). IR (KBr, cm–1): 3342s (br), 1620s, 1551s, 1431s, 1376s, 1162w, 1112w, 1058w, 1037w, 732m, 663m (Figure S4, ). UV DRS (solid) 250 nm, 275 nm, 310 nm (shoulder).

cln_elements.content:
To study the thermal stability, a thermogravimetric analysis was performed on both compounds 1 and 2 (Figure ). Crystalline samples were heated from 30 to 900 °C in air at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. An initial weight loss of approximately 19.0% over a temperature range of 40–140 °C was observed for compound 1. This could be attributed to the loss of eight coordinated water molecules per formula unit (calculated 19.2%). In the range of 140–350 °C, a further loss of 4.9% (calc 4.8%) could be the loss of two water molecules per formula unit. The weight loss of 51.1% (520–700 °C, calc 50.9%) is attributed to the removal and decomposition of the btc ligand and the formation of calcium oxide.

As for compound 2, the weight loss of 11.9% in three steps over the range of 40–225 °C corresponds to the removal of three water molecules (calc. 11.6%), and all coordinated waters are removed at this stage. In the 450–700 °C range, a weight loss of 61.2% is observed in two steps. This is caused by the decomposition and removal of pzc and btc ligands (calc. 64.2%).

UV–vis Spectroscopy

In order to investigate the electronic structure of the compounds, the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) of 1 and 2 has been studied. The UV–vis spectra of both ligands in aqueous solution and solid samples have been also recorded for comparison and are presented in (Figures s10–s13). The UV–vis spectra of free Hpzc ligand in aqueous solution exhibits three bands at 205, 268, and 312 nm. The two strong bands at higher energy level are assigned to π–π* transitions and the weak band to n–π* transition. The strong π–π* transition band of free H3btc ligand in aqueous solution is located at 209 nm with a shoulder at 238 nm. The n–π* transition band at ∼294 nm of free H3btc ligand is very weak. The transition band positions of the solid free ligand samples in their UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra are rather different from the solution absorption spectra. The DRS of pzc shows two broad bands at 250 nm (shoulder at 210 nm) and 315 nm. The btc ligand has two bands at 250 nm (shoulder at 210 nm) and 285 nm. The bands at lower energy can be assigned to the n–π* transition, which is stronger in solid state samples.

The UV-vis spectra of free Hpzc ligand in aqueous solution exhibits three bands at 205, 268, and 312 nm. The two strong bands at higher energy level are assigned to π-π* transitions and the weak band to n-π* transition. The strong π-π* transition band of free H3btc ligand in aqueous solution is located at 209 nm with a shoulder at 238 nm. The n-π* transition band at ~294 nm of free H3btc ligand is very weak. The transition band positions of the solid free ligand samples in their UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra are rather different from the solution absorption spectra. The DRS of pzc shows two broad bands at 250 nm (shoulder at 210 nm) and 315 nm. The btc ligand has two bands at 250 nm (shoulder at 210 nm) and 285 nm. The bands at lower energy can be assigned to the n-π* transition, which is stronger in solid state samples.
